Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They notice the need to use protective equipment and follow hygiene steps more consistently.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I stood in the courthouse restroom, scrubbing the sinks with gloved hands, my mind half on the task and half on the clock. As a housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to follow every safety and hygiene protocol—gloves, mask, disinfectant, the works. Lately, management had been stricter, and I’d noticed some coworkers skipping steps. I promised myself I wouldn’t cut corners, even if it meant running late. But today, I was also due in courtroom 3B in twenty minutes, not as a cleaner, but as an advocate for a client at a minor hearing. The stakes weren’t high, but my client still deserved my full attention and best effort. I glanced at my watch, feeling the pressure mount. If I rushed the cleaning, I could make it to the hearing on time, but I’d be betraying my commitment to safety. If I stayed and did the job right, I’d risk being late and letting my client down. My hands trembled as I rinsed the rag, torn between two worlds, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
